projectDesc.p: The Texting Wilde Project's aim is prepare machine-readable versions of pre-1945 biographical texts relating to Oscar Wilde for large-scale analysis.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained. However, TEI markup has been applied (within quotation marks) to material within quotation marks, using said or quote. Titles of books, periodicals, etc. that are enclosed in quotation marks in the original have been enclosed in title tags, with the rend attribute and the values dq (for double quotation marks) or sq (for single quotation marks).

hyphenation.p: Hyphens are retained for all words hyphenated over a page break.

segmentation.p: seg tags are used to enclose multiple said units that form a single unit of speech or conversation. type is used with the values of said (for a speech by an individual) or conversation for an exchange between two or more people.

head.title: Mr. Cotter Morison — My friend Mr. Frederic Harrison and his hatred of war — A charming writer — Sutton Place and its present possessor — Tennyson and his forgotten road — Thackeray in society — My blunder — Mr. Edmund Gosse — His literary powers — Frederick Locker — Mr. Alfred Austin — A dedication by Austin Dobson — A genial personality — 'Toby, M.P.' — Mr. John Morley.

div.p:
Literary people have always greatly attracted me. Amongst many whom I have known I particularly remember Matthew Arnold, Walter Pater, Froude,
Hepworth Dixon (now, I fancy, almost forgotten), and Ouida, whilst I must not forget that brilliant writer over whom I think it is best to believe that a dark cloud of insanity settled — I mean Oscar Wilde. He it was who obtained Zola's autograph for my birthday-book, on which occasion he wrote me the following letter:

body.p: I would have answered your charming letter before, but the death of poor dear Lytton has quite upset me. We had become during the last year very great friends, and I had seen him only a few days before he died, lying in Pauline Borghese's lovely room at the Embassy, and full of charm and grace and tenderness.

His funeral, in spite of the hideous Protestant service, was most impressive; the purple-covered bier with its one laurel wreath being a solemn note of colour and sadness in the midst of the gorgeous uniforms of the Ambassadors.
He was a man of real artistic temperament. I had grown to be very fond of him, and he was most kind always to me.
By all means send your book: I will get Zola's name. Poor Maupassant is dying, I fear.
body.closer: Believe me, dear Lady Dorothy, Sincerely yours, Oscar Wilde.
